intro: Godetia quadrivulnera var. davyi, commonly known as the Desert Evening Primrose, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is characterized by its yellow, tubular flowers that bloom in the evening, attracting nocturnal pollinators such as moths. The plant has hairy, glandular leaves and produces capsule fruits that contain numerous small, smooth seeds. It thrives in arid and semi-arid environments, demonstrating drought tolerance and adapted root systems. Botanically, it belongs to the family Malvaceae and is valued for its ornamental and ecological significance in desert ecosystems.
